Title.evidence: Long-term Effectiveness of Fluoroscopy-Guided Foam Sclerotherapy for Varicose Veins: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at the authors' center from August 1, 2011, to May 31, 2016.

Participants.evidence: Participants were consecutive patients with varicose veins in the legs.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved fluoroscopy-guided foam sclerotherapy, with no comparator group mentioned.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the long-term effectiveness of fluoroscopy-guided foam sclerotherapy for varicose veins in the legs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the recurrence of varicose veins, defined as their presence regardless of symptoms, assessed at the last follow-up in May 2022.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 94 patients (58.3 ± 7.8 years; 43 men; 119 legs) were included in the final analysis.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 94 patients (58.3 ± 7.8 years; 43 men; 119 legs) were included in the final analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The recurrence rate was 30.9% (29/94), with 26.6% (25/94) for the great saphenous vein and 4.3% (4/94) for the small saphenous vein (P < .001).

Harms.evidence: Hyperpigmentation occurred in 11.8% (14/119) of legs. No stroke, deep vein thrombosis, or pulmonary embolism was reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
